oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home of Mr. Manning, Knoxville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods
African Americans -- Dwellings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-story Queen Anne Victorian frame house on a flat lot, with two cross gables, two brick chimneys, and a small yard surrounded by a picket fence.

This photograph, which was captioned, for purposes of display at the Paris Exposition of 1900, as "Home of Mr. Manning, Knoxville, Tenn." is one of at least four of African American businesses and homes in Knoxville that are part of a group of 500 images that were gathered by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway. The purpose of the photographic exhibit in Paris was to show the history and present status of African Americans. The Library of Congress holds 220 of these photographs, including 24 taken in Knoxville (4), Nashville (16), Chattanooga (3), and Memphis (1), Tennessee. The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. During his time at Fisk, he taught during summer breaks in Tennessee's rural areas, before continuing his graduate work at Harvard. In 1897, DuBois joined the faculty at Atlanta University and a good number of the photographs in this collection were also taken there.
